conclusion: The graph shows velocity vs time for two objects A and B, both starting at the same location and moving in the same direction.
Object A is represented by straight line segments and Object B by curved lines on the graph.
Velocity v₀ is the maximum velocity shown on the graph, with time points marked as t₁, t₂, t₃, and t₄.
Displacement of an object is the area under the velocity-time curve, and separation is the difference in their displacements.
From O to t₁: Object A's velocity increases linearly from 0, Object B's velocity decreases from v₀.
From t₁ to t₂: Object A's velocity continues to increase linearly, Object B's velocity continues to decrease.
From t₂ to t₃: Object A's velocity decreases linearly from v₀, Object B's velocity increases from near 0.
From t₃ to t₄: Object A's velocity decreases linearly to 0, Object B's velocity increases to v₀.
The objects move apart when one object has a higher velocity than the other, increasing separation.
From O to t₁: B is faster than A, separation increasing.
From t₁ to when velocities equal: B is faster than A, separation increasing.
From when velocities equal to t₂: A is faster than B, separation decreasing.
From t₂ to t₃: A is faster than B, separation decreasing.
From t₃ to when velocities equal again: A is faster than B, separation decreasing.
From when velocities equal to t₄: B is faster than A, separation increasing.
Separation is maximum when objects stop moving apart and start moving closer, occurring when velocities are equal.
Velocities are equal at two points: between t₁ and t₂, and between t₃ and t₄.
Maximum separation occurs at the first point where velocities are equal, between t₁ and t₂.
The two objects are farthest apart at the moment when their velocities become equal for the first time, between t₁ and t₂.
